PETITION.TITLE: Joint Australian-United States Electronic Communication Facility, Watsonia Army Barracks, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Joint Australian-United States Electronic Communication Facility, Watsonia Army Barracks, Victoria
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains electronic communication facilities, operated by Australian and American personel, that gives the United States the ability to pin-point soviet nuclear submarines, hidden in the Oceans.

2. This would make it possible for U.S. killer-submarines to destroy all Soviet nuclear submarines, while the U.S. nuclear submarines launch their missiles in a ''first strike'' attack. This makes Watsonia a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have a disastrous effect on Melbourne.
3. The 'joint U.S.-Australian' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menace to nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should close the 'Joint Australian-U.S.' electronic communication facilities in the Watsonia Army barracks.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled: the petition of the undersigned Australian citizens respectfully showeth that:

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Grimes) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Automotive Industry Authority Act 1984 to promote the development of motor vehicles, and motor vehicle components, of Australian design, and for related purposes.
Bill presented by Senator Grimes, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill proposes to amend the Automotive Industry Authority Act 1984 to incorporate the motor vehicles and components development grants scheme announced by the Government on 29 May 1984. The grants scheme is designed to provide financial assistance to the Australian automotive industry to promote the development of motor vehicles and automotive components of Australian design.

The Government announced in October last year that financial assistance of up to $150m would be provided to Australian companies engaged in the research, development and design of motor vehicles and automotive components which are either new or substantially improved.
The Government also announced that the Automotive Industry Authority would be responsible for the administration of the scheme.
To put the design scheme in perspective I will reiterate the key elements of the Government's motor vehicle industry policy.

The Government's policy has two fundamental objectives: To preserve a substantial vehicle manufacturing industry in this country, and to place the industry in a better competitive position against imports.
The Government believes that the expectations of Australian consumers are more likely to be realised if there is a strong vehicle manufacturing industry able to compete vigorously with imports.
To achieve this the local industry must become more competitive in all aspects.
Previous Government policies have not achieved this objective.

The assistance framework which had been built up since the 1960s, primarily in answer to short-term crisis containment, was aimed largely at protecting the Australian automotive industry from import competition. As a result the industry has become inward looking and the incentive to develop progressive and innovative design has diminished. The Government considers this situation to be no longer tenable.

Our decision to introduce the grants scheme is based on a belief that if there is to be a future for the Australian automotive industry, and if it is to compete on world markets, then there needs to be more emphasis placed on design.

Manufacturers must become more competitive internationally and more export oriented if they are to have any long term future. In this context, excellence and uniqueness in design are of the utmost importance.

Good design allows a manufacturer to differentiate his product from his competitors', thereby creating new markets, meeting competition and possibly becoming a market leader, rather than simply a market follower.
Improvements in design should result in more technically efficient products with greater reliability, better performance and easier and less costly maintenance.
However, for design to produce these benefits, it is becoming increasingly apparent that it must be an integral part of the corporate strategy of the firm.

At present the industry in Australia is heavily reliant on overseas companies for designs. Of the thirteen models produced in Australia, the Ford Falcon is the only uniquely Australian motor vehicle. Other Australian manufactured models are designed overseas, with local input mainly to satisfy Australian design rules and domestic driving conditions.

The Car Industry Council, in its report to the Government in December 1983, expressed concern at the downward trend in the number of skilled personnel involved in design in the Australian automotive industry. I quote from that report:

The Council recognises that the downward trend results from the increasing costs associated with the development of new models, and that the relatively limited size of the Australian market would certainly not, other things being equal, encourage world manufacturers to maintain unique Australian design activities. Rather, Australian producers would increasingly purchase designs from overseas.
The Council believes that there is no action with the industry itself can take, unaided, to reverse this trend.

Given, however, the introduction of appropriate incentives by government, the Council believes that the decline can be slowed or stopped. If this were to happen it is conceivable that, in the longer term, the downward trend could be reversed. World developments in design, including international computer linkages, could create an environment where Australia could become a world centre for certain types of design work.

The Government believes that the grants scheme, together with the other policy measures announced last year, will positively assist the industry to address this downward trend. By contributing to improvement in the industry's competitiveness, the grants scheme will also help to enhance employment opportunities in the industry.
The arrangements for the grants scheme, to which I will refer shortly, are modelled, to a large degree, on relevant provisions of the industrial research and development incentives scheme.

The Government has decided however, that the introduction of the grants scheme will not preclude the automotive industry from the industrial research and development incentives scheme. If the industry were to be excluded from that scheme it would be denied the opportunity to receive support in relation to commencement grants, research and development of non-automotive products, and research and development of new manufacturing processes, none of which will be covered by the automotive grants scheme.

Eligibility for grant assistance will be limited to companies engaged in, or intending to become engaged in, the manufacture in Australia of motor vehicles and components covered by the passenger motor vehicle manufacturing plan.

Financial support will be provided for product development projects involving activities such as systematic experimentation or analysis in a field of science or technology for the purpose of devising or developing new or substantially improved material products, and the design of such products.

With the diversity of motor vehicle model types and component specifications, it is likely that companies in the industry will increasingly turn to the use of computer-aided design and model testing techniques.
In recognition of this, the scheme will also cover projects for the development of computer software programs intended to enhance a company's general capability to undertake product development work.

The Government will provide the Automotive Industry Authority with guideline directions to be followed by the Authority in the performance of its functions and the exercise of its powers under the scheme. The guidelines will contain a detailed presentation of the Government's motor vehicle industry policy. Such directions will ensure that the projects selected by the Authority for financial assistance will promote the kind of restructuring and reorientation of the industry that the Government believes is necessary.

It is anticipated that the guideline directions will be introduced upon the commencement of the Act, and these will require the Authority to be satisfied that the projects assisted promote one or more of the objectives of the policy.

The guideline directions will also deal with the project agreements which may be made under this Bill. The directions will permit such agreements, in addition to dealing with the particular project, to include provisions which impose conditions or requirements that promote the attainment of the Government's motor vehicle industry policy.

In assessing the level of support to be provided, the Authority will be asked to give particular attention to the extent to which the project will improve the applicant's ability to contribute to the sound development of the automotive industry, including improvement in its ability to compete in the domestic market against imports, and to develop export markets
The Authority will also be asked to consider:
the extent of benefits likely to accrue to other local businesses and industries;
the time frame likely to be involved in bringing the results of the project to the commercial phase;
the overall funding arrangements for the project, including funding which the applicant is prepared to commit, and assistance being provided to the applicant from other sources; and
the extent to which any dependence on overseas technology or other factors may restrict the applicant's ability to exploit the results of the project in international markets.

Judgments on these factors cannot be based on general criteria but have to take into account what is actually happening in the industry and how the project would relate to the activities of other companies in the industry. The Government believes that the Authority, through its role of monitoring industry developments and liaising and consulting with industry participants, is in the best position to evaluate projects and determine whether they are consistent with the Government's policy for the industry.

Where a firm, and the project it proposes, satisfy the prescribed eligibility criteria, the project will be ranked by the Authority against the kind of guideline directions previously mentioned, and other eligible projects.

If the Authority decides to assist a project, the assistance will be in the form of taxable cash grants, provided progressively over the life of the project, equivalent to up to 50 per cent of the expenditure incurred on the project. Sufficient flexibility has been provided in the Bill for grants to be paid at a rate above 50 per cent if the Government believes this is necessary.
There is also provision for firms which have limited financial resources to receive grant payments in advance.

In addition to funding company projects, projects undertaken in government financed research institutions may be funded under the grants scheme, where it is considered in the public interest to do so. This will permit the Commonwealth to seek to achieve commercial application of the results of research and development undertaken in such institutions.

It is intended that any such commercial development work will be contracted out to industry through a tender process with the Commonwealth meeting the cost. The outcome of such projects would remain the property of the Commonwealth and the rights for commercial production of successful developments would be put to tender.
Financial Impact Statement

This Bill includes a provision to restrict the total amount of grants payable during each year of the scheme to that amount which the Government notifies to the Authority is available for payment or commitment in that year. The Government has decided that the motor vehicles and components development grants scheme will be subject to a maximum appropriation of $150m over the 5 years to 1988-89. No funds were allocated for the scheme in the 1984-85 Budget, however, the government has approved the commitment of up to $20m for grant agreements entered into during the 1984-85 financial year, with appropriation for the committed funds to be sought in the 1985-86 Budget process. I commend this Bill to the Senate

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Macklin) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution so as to ensure that the Members of the Parliament of the Commonwealth and of the Parliaments of the States and of self-governing territories are chosen directly and democratically by the people.
Bill presented by Senator Macklin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This is a revised version of a Bill first introduced to this Parliament on 2 April 1984. Extensive discussions since that time have led to revisions being incorporated to clarify and improve certain aspects of the Bill. The revised Bill has the same intention as the original Bill presented last year-namely, to guarantee the right to vote and to guarantee that every citizen's vote will be treated equally.

Of course, as many honourable senators would recall, a substantially similar Bill was introduced on 8 November, 1973 by the then Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam. The introduction of that Bill was the implementation of a promise made by Mr Whitlam on behalf of the Australian Government at the Australian Constitutional Convention held in Sydney in September of that year. While that Bill had the same aim as this one, the then Opposition, under the leadership of Mr Snedden, opposed the Bill. Basically, it appears to me, because it felt that the stated principle was not being implemented by Mr Whitlam's Bill. The Opposition argued, quite correctly I believe, that by making electorates equal in the sense that they were to have an equal number of people in them, would not give votes equal value.

The argument advanced by some people is that from a work load point of view these members still have to represent people who are not registered to vote and consequently should be allowed to have them counted in the numbers. From my point of view, this is going about things the wrong way around. Indeed, I believe that we would be far better off encouraging these people to become Australian citizens, if they are not already, and to register to vote.

Given the strong feeling exhibited in 1973 about whether electorates should be divided on the basis of electors or people, I had waited until the Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill had passed through Parliament before raising the matter again. I had thought that we might see a debate at that time on whether electorates should continue to be divided along current lines-that is, number of electors-or whether the Government would take up the Whitlam proposal again and attempt to divide electorates along the lines of numbers of people in them. No debate arose and I take heart from the fact that the present Labor Government is quite happy to accept what I take to be the Opposition line, that things remain the way they are. As a result of this, I have amended Mr Whitlam's original Bill so that the numbers ascertained in respect of divisions shall be, as nearly as practicable, the same in respect of the numbers of electors rather than the numbers of people in each electorate. This concept should now have the support of the vast majority of senators and members in this Parliament. Although it is a principle which appears to have the almost complete support of Federal parliamentarians, and indeed the people of Australia, it is a principle which is obviously not supported by all parliamentarians at the State level.

I believe that the time has come for the people of the States and the self-governing Territories to have their say on whether or not their current situation should be allowed to continue. Unfortunately, no State Parliament requires a vote of electors in order to change its own Constitution in this regard. Indeed, not even the Federal Constitution requires that change. But I believe it is time that we enshrined the principle in the Federal Constitution so that future governments are not persuaded to change the principle now established for purely political gain.

There are two other changes which have been made to Mr Whitlam's original Bill which I will mention briefly here, before moving on to changes made to the Bill I introduced last year. The first of these is a purely technical one to rectify an inconsistency in Mr Whitlam's wording of clause 5 and clause 7 of the Bill. As to the substances of clause 5, which has become clause 4 in this revised version of the Bill, the proposed alteration to section 30 of the Constitution has been refined to ensure that the Parliament may provide for the continuing operation of laws relating to the enfranchisement of non-citizens who are currently entitled to vote.

The second change to Mr Whitlam's Bill was to allow parliaments to decide to grant the right to vote to people under the age of 18 if they so desire. Arguments in favour of providing for a younger voting age remain the same as when this Bill was introduced last year-although I recognise that the proposal may be controversial. My reason for incorporating the provision is quite simple. Given the difficulties in making amendments to the Constitution, I do not believe that we should enshrine the 18-year-old age limit into the Constitution as the time may well come-even if it is 20 or 30 years away-that we may wish to give 17 or even 16 year-olds the vote. This issue was raised in particular relation to 17 year-olds being conscripted to fight in Vietnam, even though they did not have the vote. It is one thing to force 6 to 15 year-olds to go to school, whether or not it is one of their own choosing, but it is quite a different matter to ask a 17 year-old to fight in a war which he or she might wish to oppose by voting for a political party which opposed such a war if he or she were entitled to vote. A vote of 17 year-olds might well have made the difference in 1969 as to who governed this country and as to whether or not this country continued to conscript people to go to Vietnam.

When this Bill was last introduced in Parliament, the question was raised as to whether the Bill would allow proportional representation and whether or not the Government of the day supported that proposal. Unfortunately, the Government did not, as it still does not; but the Bill does allow for that type of system to exist, as it already does in Tasmania. As I said in my second reading speech on the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill, the fact that proportional representation for the House of Representatives was missing from that Bill effectively means that the Bill did not really grapple with the last major task of reform in the electoral process. This is a bitter disappointment to many people in the community who feel that it is a necessary move that we must take. I hope that in the future it will be seen to be a necessary reform and that eventually it will be taken. The acceptance of this Bill will certainly do nothing to hinder that development.

As my colleague, Senator Jack Evans, said in his second reading speech on the aforementioned Bill, the omission of proportional representation means that Australia continues with the very lopsided, winner takes all system of having governments elected. 'Winner takes all' follows automatically from a system under which there is a single candidate elected for an electorate and a candidate has to attract only 50 per cent of the vote plus one to win. There is no justice and no fairness in that kind of system. I think most people in Australia are now aware that the newer countries which have been formed since this country was federated have opted for proportional representation. Honourable senators may wish to look back over this part of Senator Evans's speech which can be found on pages 3058 and 3059 of Hansard for 30 November 1983.

I now wish to draw honourable senators' attention to certain other provisions in the Bill. Provision for the repeal of section 25 has been retained from the earlier version of the Bill. Section 25 of the Constitution provides that if by law of any State any persons of any race are disqualified from voting at elections for the more numerous houses of the State, then in reckoning the number of people of the State or of the Commonwealth, persons of that race resident in that State shall not be counted. This is an archaic and objectionable provision. It is not within the spirit of the wishes of any political party in this place and the Bill provides for the repeal of that section.

The proposed repeal of section 41, which was not included in the original version of the Bill, arises for two reasons. First section 41 has ceased to have any practical operation following a High Court decision in 1983, secondly, if retained in the Constitution, section 41 would conflict with the proposed amendment to section 30.

The original Bill proposed amendments to section 75 to confer original jurisdiction on the High Court in relation to matters arising in the electoral provisions of State or Commonwealth law and to ensure that the electors are able to take action to enforce those provisions. The proposed paragraph in this revised version of the bill has been altered in two respects. First, the words ''or involving the interpretation of'' have been inserted to make section 75 consistent with section 76. Secondly, the jurisdictional safeguards, which originally applied in relation to elections for the house of representatives, have now been extended to include senate elections and elections for representatives of the Territories in the Commonwealth Parliament.

Proposed new section 106A, originally dealing with the election of members of State parliaments, has now been altered in several respects. First, the proposed section now extends to the parliaments of self-governing territories. This change is reflected in the alteration to the long title of the Bill. The provisions of the section now apply to both general elections and by-elections-apart from the penultimate paragraph which applies to general elections only. The revised wording makes it clear that people can only vote at elections in the State or Territory in which they are normally resident, but does not, of course, prevent them from voting due to temporary absence from home. As with section 30, revisions to the proposed section 106A ensure that Parliament may provide for the continuing operation of laws enfranchising non-citizens who are currently entitled to vote.

In the event of non-compliance with the 'one-vote, one-value' principle of section 106A, a further amendment provides for the whole State or Territory to be deemed one electorate for the purposes of a general election. This covers the situation where there is insufficient time for a redistribution before an election. The amendment also explains why a commencement date, which had been included in the original Bill, has now been omitted. The inclusion of the 'fall-back' position obviates the need to give the states some time to comply with the Bill's provisions. In addition, the amendment addresses the argument that the Bill in its original form might have empowered the Commonwealth to redraw State electoral boundaries which had been declared invalid.

The final amendment to proposed section 106A ensures that the Senate voting system would be adopted in a situation where a State general election was held in accordance with the penultimate paragraph of the proposed section.

One final point, proposed new section 122A imposes similar requirements to elections for representatives of the Territories in either house of the Commonwealth Parliament as those applicable to elections for representatives of the States. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
