SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the Senate is debating the failure of the Government to protect the people of Australia from abuses of trade union power. No other country has indulged the whole gamut of union activities and union power the way Australia has. Successive Australian governments, whether Liberal-National Party or Labor, Federal and State, by legislation and administrative practice have protected, reinforced and promoted the unionisation of Australia. While that might have been a worthy aim initially, it has now been abused by irresponsible union leaders. We have reached the stage now, as both the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, and Senator Collard said, when members of the public are totally fed up with union abuses of power and the tragic consequences of that on Australian society. The Liberal Party knows it; the National Party knows it; the Australian Labor Party does not know it. It does not want to know it because it is beholden to the union movement for its candidates, such as Senator Cook, and for the money the union movement puts into its coffers.

SPEECH.PARA: Unionism as it is known in Australia is out of date. It is an anachronism we can no longer afford. What was relevant and worthy in 1885 is now doing a major disservice to the nation in 1985. It hits at current production. It affects future consumption. It destroys investor and entrepreneurial confidence. It destroys profitability. Above all, it is the very converse of its original intention. The original intentions of unionism were to promote the individual's right to work, the right to work with dignity and independence. The very thing that it set out to do 100 years ago is now the direct converse of the effect of unions in Australian society.

Are we a civilised society when we have picket lines? Are we civilised when people who do not want to work deny the right to others? They not only deny other people the right to work but also go around running picket lines, calling people scabs, intimidating and bullying people, and carrying out acts of thuggery that lead at times to the loss of human life. That is not the sort of Australia in which I want to live. That is not the sort of Australia for which I want to be a legislator. Yet this is what the union movement is about. That is why the people of Australia have had enough of it.

So far in this debate we have heard from the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, who obviously did not have his mind on the job. He seldom makes a good speech these days and this was one of his worst. The sole point that Senator Button brought up was the fact that it was a Queensland matter, not a national matter. He said it was a Queensland affair and so it did not matter. I have news for Senator Button.

Senator Jack Evans rambled on about the history of the movement. The interesting thing was that he missed the most important part of the history in dealing with the origins of the Queensland problem, and that was that the administration felt that because the union workers were moonlighting and doing so much contract work on the side it might as well officialise it and go to contract labour from the start. That is the origin of the whole thing. Senator Cook went on as usual, as a former trade union official, and demonstrated why, when he ran the campaign in Forrest, Peter Drummond's vote went up. Everywhere Senator Cook went the Liberal vote climbed through the roof, particularly in the industrialised town. While I am on the matter of Labor speakers, why do not the Labor senators from Queensland get up to speak on this matter? Where are they hiding? Why are they not speaking on a matter that is vitally important to them and to their State?

The Australian public wants change in our industrial relations. It sees that as the most important thing before us. The Australian public wants common sense in the way we manage our industrial affairs. Tax reform is quite secondary, even though it is important. If we proceed in the area of industrial relations, in the way we have in this country we will end up as a Third World country. Living standards are falling. As Senator Townley says on many occasions, the average debt per head of Australians is more than it is in Argentina, Chile or Mexico. This is largely due to the fact that we have a monopoly on the provision of labour by the unions of this country. Australia must have a free market for labour. We need legislation only to prevent exploitation of labour by employers. Present legislation exploits employers and the country. This country has to earn money through its industrial production. We cannot pay more and more to greedy unionists and shut out the world. If that happens, in the end the country will go bankrupt. If there is one asset which we have in this country it is the Australian work force. It can compete with any work force in the world. It is intelligent and resourceful. It is conscientious, dedicated and hard working, but it cannot work under the union system that we have imposed on society today.

The Labor Party has not realised that community attitudes to unions have changed very dramatically in the last year or two. That is demonstrated by the Queensland troubles. The Queensland Premier has wide support. Today's Courier-Mail, under the heading 'Strike right second to to power need', stated:
The right to a power supply is more important than the right to strike, says a major public opinion poll.
But most of the people surveyed believed in the right to strike as a general principle.
Of the people surveyed, 73.5 percent, particularly National and Liberal voters, said workers should not cut the supply of electricity in support of strike action.
Among Labor voters, almost 50 percent said electricity supply workers should not have the right to strike.

The actions of the Queensland Government are supported not only in Queensland but also right across Australia. Australians want three things in industrial relations: They want voluntary unions, no picket lines and no strikes in essential services. They see unionism in the modern age as being a matter of election; not of compulsion. A voluntary union system is what the community demands. The community upholds the right to strike. That is not challenged, except in relation to essential industries. One of the big changes that the Labor Party has not picked up is that the community no longer believes that if people want to strike they can deny the opportunity for others in the community who have the qualifications and the will to work, to take their places. The second essential difference is in the matter of strikes by workers employed in essential services. Society today is far too complex, far too interdependent, for a crowd that has a monopoly on the supply of something like electricity to hold the community to ransom, particularly when one realises that most of the people who went on strike in Queensland were on incomes of around $40,000 to $50,000 a year. They were not scraping along just above the dole line. In a nutshell, we are moving to a society that will have voluntary unionism. Strikes by those involved in essential services will be forbidden under legislation. Workers who want to strike may do so but they have to expect that others will take their places. We will see an arbitration system that sets minimal wages only and does not tie up the whole ball game as is the case at present.

The debate today has been brought about by the action last night of the Transport Workers Union of Australia in blockading Queensland. This anarchistic action has the support of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Federal Government. Today the ACTU called on 160 unions to run a hit list against 51 so-called Queensland companies. I want to touch on two very important points, the ACTU's position and that of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The ACTU's position is a double cross. It broke the one and only rule of labour relations in Australia; that is, that a striking union has the support of the ACTU and the Labor government. That has been the one inviolate rule of the labour movement.

The history of the strike in Queensland is that Mr Kelty went to Queensland on 21 February. At that time the strike was unresolved. By 6.15 on the night of 21 February, the strike was over. Mr Kelty pulled the rug out from the striking Queensland Electrical Trades Union members. Mr Dolan, the head of the ACTU, sent Mr Kelty. The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, Senator Button and all the Labor Cabinet, including the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, who is in the chamber, must have known and been party to this act of treachery with respect to the labour movement. What is the ACTU now doing? It is covering up with nationwide strikes. It is quite careless of the effect of this strike action on the loss of jobs, profits and exports.

On Saturday afternoon I flew from Townsville to Brisbane. Eight ships, which are vital to Australia's export trade, were anchored off Hay Point. Those ships are awaiting loading as a consequence of this problem in Queensland. The action in which the ACTU is involved is unlawful. It is a flagrant, wilful breach of section 45D of the Trade Practices Act because it is a gross secondary boycott on a national scale. As Senator Collard said, it also breaches section 92 of the Constitution, which provides that trade between the States is to be free and unimpeded.

I now turn to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister is Prime Minister for all Australians. He is not the Prime Minister of just the ACTU or the labour movement. He is not the Prime Minister only of New South Wales and Victoria; he is the Prime Minister of Queensland, Tasmania, the Northern Territory and all the rest of Australia. As a Queenslander I say that we are Australians first and Queenslanders second. We have a Prime Minister who I would have thought would have been bound by ALP resolutions one of which states that 'a Labor government will direct its program towards achieving a just industrial society in which all Australians have a right to work'.

This Prime Minister supports and the Cabinet supports the law breaking by the ACTU. The Government says that it will not enforce section 45D and that it will not support the Constitution. I would have thought that a Prime Minister would be bound to uphold the law unless he wanted to take the community as a whole into anarchy, which is what will happen if the Prime Minister does not get to the root of the problem which the community wants fixed. The community wants the industrial relations problem fixed. It does not want the diversion of an attack on the Queensland legislation. The Queensland Government has done the best it can in very difficult circumstances. Let us hear from the Labor Party what it will do. Let us not have a character assassination of the Premier of Queensland. Let us have something constructive from the Labor Party.

This Labor Party is absolutely careless of the consequences to Queensland of this boycott legislation. It is careless of the consequences for primary industry-for the beef and sugar industries, It is careless of the effects of the boycott on manufacturing industry. It is careless of the effects of the boycott on the exporting industries of coal and alumina. The Labor Party is quite careless of the consequences of the boycott for Australian industry, of which Queensland is an integral part. We have a Prime Minister who not only is failing to uphold the law but also is condoning and encouraging the breaking of it. If he holds the law in contempt can he wonder at all if the public does the same to him and to the laws he wants to make?
We have aimless leadership from the Prime Minister. We do not have a hawk; we have a chook running this country.

This is the latest act in a long line of careless government. The Labor Government does not care about the unemployed. The Labor Government does not care about the sick. The Labor Government does not care about business. The Labor Government does not care about the farmers or primary industry. The Labor Government does not care about the defence forces. Above all, the Labor Government does not care about ordinary Australians who are going about their ordinary jobs in an orderly, predictable and responsible way. This Government has failed to protect Australia in all ways, and no more strikingly so than in its failure to attack the abuse of power by the bullies in the union movement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposition, as it is termed, is divisive and likely to exacerbate the present situation in Queensland. The proposition contains the hidden allegation that the union movement is at war with the Australian people, a tragic allegation when the problem in Queensland must be settled and must be settled as soon as possible. There is no doubt that this matter has to be disposed of. It will be disposed of ultimately, and the quicker it is disposed of the better.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator MacGibbon said: 'Let us not have a character assassination of the Premier of Queensland'. I agree with that, particularly because this matter must be settled. But having said that we should not assassinate the character of one of the essential parties to any agreement that comes about, Senator MacGibbon immediately assassinated the characters of Bill Kelty and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who also have to be part of any settlement that takes place. Senator MacGibbon said that Kelty pulled the rug out from the unionists in Queensland, that he betrayed, in effect, the very people he was meant to serve. What sort of settlement will we get, what sort of negotiations will we have, if one of the parties essential to those negotiations is pilloried, cursed and made out to be treacherous to the people he is meant to serve? Certainly we should not assassinate the character of the Premier of Queensland. I will not be doing that. But certainly, if that proposition is to be put forward, the character of everybody who is essential to the proper settlement of this dispute should be spared and the matter set down for discussion, not in terms of some sort of football match where some sort of dramatic win is looked for, but in terms of a negotiated settlement.

Throughout this whole debate it has to be remembered that the problem in Queensland at the moment has been brought about by the fact that one of the parties will not negotiate. How can a proper settlement take place, how can this matter be disposed of, if people will not talk? If this is going to be an Indian arm wrestling contest, where the person who crumbles to the table or falls to the ground will be the loser, where are we going to get? Certainly, if that is the attitude that is going to be taken we have to expect that the unions will react.

Senator MacGibbon said that unionism was all right in the 1890s, that it had a function to serve then, but that that function has fundamentally changed. The inference in that proposition is that unionism as we know it now should disappear, that unionism should undergo a fundamental change. That, in effect, means that the very institution of unionism is under attack. In the situation we are now discussing what is happening is that the attack is being made on the institution of unionism. If that happens it is to be expected that a union will do what any institution which is under attack would do-that is, defend itself. I simply suggest that it would be better if propositions such as the one that unionism must disappear or, at the very least, undergo fundamental change, were not put at this stage because that sort of proposition only exacerbates the situation.

The other proposition put by Senator MacGibbon was that we must have free market forces operating in the employment field. The difficulty with that sort of suggestion is that it makes labour a commodity, as coal is a commodity. It devalues the very thrust of what work is all about. It is the means ordinary, decent people have of keeping their families, of manifesting their purpose in this world and of making a career. Work is simply not like coal. It is simply not a commodity that can be bartered and sold. It is more than that. If the Queensland Government has gone ahead on the basis that it is dealing with merely a commodity, as coal is a commodity, and the people who work contribute their very bodies and their very souls to carrying out their jobs, of course we will have difficulty. The attitude with which the Government approaches these people must lead inevitably to conflict and to the sorts of difficulties we have now.

It was proposed that the Australian Labor Party is beholden to unionism and that in some way the people in the Labor Party have a debt to unionism. I suggest that the people in Australia as a whole have a debt to unionism. The quality of life we as a nation enjoy is in large measure due to the union movement. That ought not be forgotten. Decent wages, decent standards of living and a decent environment would not be available to the majority of Australians were it not for unions. If it is perceived to be all right to take an event or an industrial action and to say that that represents what the union movement as a whole is all about, it will make it very difficult to settle this dispute because it is a false perception. As I have said, the conditions the unions have obtained are enjoyed by a vast majority of Australians, even by those who never contributed anything towards obtaining them. That has to be remembered. People are in the habit of denigrating, even cursing, unions and at the same time making use of the very benefits of for which they have fought. Senator MacGibbon said that in the 1890s unions had right on their side. In the 1890s unionists were shot and killed for the attempts they made to get the sorts of conditions that we now accept as ordinary, everyday things. It is a lack of a sense of propriety to enjoy the benefits obtained by unions and then to pillory them for taking the sort of action that has obtained those benefits.

As I said before, without unions labour becomes a commodity, a thing for sale to anyone who wants to buy it, instead of being the means by which a person can keep himself and his family in reasonable conditions, and that is not to be forgotten. Let there be no mistake that the vast majority of Australians would have a lower standard of living if it were not for the unions. I mentioned some factors and I will mention others. Workers compensation, safety legislation, reasonable hours of labour and paid holidays are some of the things that employees in Australia enjoy because of unionism.

Let me make it quite clear that at times unions, like other institutions in society, such as business, schools or any institution that one cares to name, do depart from what is desirable. I am not saying that unionism is the greatest thing that has happened, that it does not make mistakes and that it does not do the wrong thing. What I am saying is that one should look at it not in terms of those things which one says that it does wrong but in terms of the overall benefits that it has brought to the society. Those overall benefits, I suggest, are much greater than the harm it has caused to this community. The number of days lost through industrial action is much less than the number lost through industrial accidents. That should not be forgotten.

Senator Collard said that nobody was put at risk by what was done in Queensland. Of course, 1,200 people were sacked and the very basis of unionism, as I have said, was attacked. Of course, the ability of the unions to put a united position and to back up that position was under attack. To say that they had nothing to lose does not accord at all with the facts. Senator Collard also said that unionism is not under attack in Queensland and that the legislation that is now in operation is not something to complain about. Part of the Electricity (Continuity of Supply) Act states, in effect, that a person shall not, either alone or in concert with any other person, omit to do any act, which omission is calculated to annoy any person on account of the job he is doing. In other words, it becomes a crime for anybody to admit to doing something, which admission might cause harm or distress. If somebody refuses to speak and thus causes annoyance to a worker because he regards him, whether rightly or wrongly, as being somebody who has broken a union rule, he can be charged and convicted of a crime. To say that that is a matter of little moment, I submit, is well clear of the mark.

A major point was made by Senator Collard in respect of the actions of the Industrial Commission in Queensland. He made a distinction between directions and recommendations. He said that, if it was a direction by the Commission, the particular organisation involved-in this case, the unions-should accept it; but, if it was only a recommendation, the institution involved-the Government-should not accept it. In other words, on the one hand the Industrial Commission should be given full faith and credit and on the other it should be ignored. That will not work if one institution has to accept it and the other does not. That is a fact of life. Again, it creates a perception by one party that it has been disadvantaged in the negotiations. In order to negotiate successfully, it must be clear to both parties-or the three parties, if three are involved-that there is at least some semblance of equality between them.

Senator Button said that the Australian Council of Trade Unions has sought to discuss the problems in Queensland with the Premier and he has refused to do so. I invite Senator Chaney, Senator MacGibbon and Senator Collard to approach the Premier to see whether he will have discussions with the ACTU. That is a practical and effective way to deal with the matter. I ask them whether, as members of his Party or of a party allied with his, they can approach him to see whether he will talk to the President and the Secretary of the ACTU-not in any way to reduce what he sees as his proper dignity, but simply to talk to them. That is one way of solving this problem. I suggest to honourable senators opposite that they take up with the Premier the proposition that some discussion should take place in order to avert what will become, it would seem, an inevitable situation of extensive disruption which nobody in his right mind can welcome.

In that context it should be said that a person who takes industrial action, a person who goes on strike and subjects himself to the consequences of criminal legislation, does not do so lightly. It is often thought that people who go on strike, face all sorts of rigours and lose income, do so in a light hearted manner. If one thinks about that proposition, it must simply fail because normal decent people do not do those sorts of things unless there is a real cause for them to do so, or at least a cause which they feel leads them to do so. When one looks at the action taken by the unionists in Queensland, one must remember that they are ordinary decent people who, until now, went about their work and who felt so strongly about a point-it is not a matter of whether one agrees with the point-that they were willing to take this dramatic action, an action which, it must be remembered, would be to their disadvantage. Finally, in regard to this situation the unions have been blamed. No real attention has been paid to what management has done.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —To argue or see the matter before the Senate today as a Queensland issue alone is to misunderstand it. The argument is about the exercise of power by elected governments and about the power of trade unions to oppose elected governments. We are not talking about the reasonable use of the strike power. Abuses of union power are occurring. The latest abuses are occurring in Queensland. They are threatening people across the land and they are particularly threatening lives and jobs in Queensland at present.

SPEECH.PARA: I enter the debate as a one-time member of the Australian Workers Union and as a long-time member of the doctors' union, the Australian Medical Association. I acknowledge the help I received from both of those bodies in terms of industrial matters. But I argue this matter against the background that all Australians, including Queenslanders, are being disadvantaged and inconvenienced, and their jobs are being threatened by what is occurring, and we fear that there is more to come. A series of events concerns us. In New South Wales there was a prolonged coal strike. This occurred when a union could not win by the procedures provided and tried to use the strike weapon. TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1985

Mr President, the 1984 Australian Labor Party policy speech by the Prime Minister re-affirmed the Labor Party's policy of smashing the tax avoidance industry-a policy that was pursued throughout our previous term of Government and a policy upon which this Government was re-elected. In his policy speech last year, the Prime Minister promised the Australian public that, once re-elected, the Government would re-introduce the twice-rejected ''bottom-of-the-harbour'' legislation-legislation that will recoup hundreds of millions of dollars from those who have sought to escape their taxation responsibilities through participation in avoidance schemes produced by the tax avoidance industry.

On 22 February 1985, when announcing the Government's legislation programme for the current sittings, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce foreshadowed the re-introduction of Bills designed to give effect to this Government's successive election undertakings to recover personal tax avoided by former owners of companies that were the subject of ''bottom-of-the-harbour'' schemes.

Mr President, this Bill is the first of the 2 Bills to which my colleague was referring. Apart from some relatively minor corrections of a more or less technical nature, this Bill is identical with a Bill introduced into this chamber on 7 September 1983 and again on 10 May 1984.

Honourable senators may recall that on both occasions the Bill was defeated on a tied vote in this chamber. Although many honourable senators will already be familiar with the important measures contained in this Bill, it is appropriate as this is a new parliament that I should outline its contents once more.
Measures to Recover Personal Tax

By far the greater part of this Bill is related to amendments to give effect to our decision that the restitution expected of those persons who benefited from the sale of shares in companies that were stripped of pre-tax profits should not be limited to the tax that ought to have been paid by the companies concerned. Rather, those persons should also pay the tax that, as shareholders or other former owners, they escaped through receipt in a non-taxable capital form of after-tax profits that, if the companies had continued to operate as going concerns, would have been taxable as dividends in their hands.

The recovery of personal tax will, however, be confined to the tax related to after-tax revenue profits of the stripped company for those years of income in respect of which primary company tax was evaded. In our view it is quite beyond argument that the revenue is just as entitled to have these tax losses made good as it is to have the lost company tax made good.

This Bill will accordingly insert in the existing recoupment tax law, rules to be applied to fix the liability of former owners of a stripped company for personal income tax on those profits on which primary company tax was evaded.

Broadly, these rules will require a former owner of a stripped company to pay income tax on the basis that the company had paid a dividend to the former owner at the time of sale of the shares. The amount of this imputed dividend will be the same proportion of the company's after-tax taxable income for the year of income in respect of which primary company tax was evaded as the proportion of the sale consideration received by that owner. The amount of after-tax taxable income will be determined after allowance has been made for the unpaid ordinary company tax that is to be recouped under the existing legislation, as proposed to be amended.

The Bill provides that a dividend will be deemed to have been paid in circumstances where the former owner of a company is liable to make good unpaid company tax on the company's taxable income, i.e., where there is a liability for vendors recoupment tax in relation to ordinary company tax or there would have been such a liability if any payments of such tax made after 25 July 1982 were disregarded. That date is, of course, the date on which the former Government announced its intention to legislate to recover unpaid company tax escaped through ''bottom-of-the-harbour'' schemes. This qualification is necessary to ensure that the liability for escaped personal income tax will not be avoided simply by making a payment of the income tax in pursuance of the former Government's announcement or of the recoupment tax legislation enacted in 1982.

The requirement that there exists or, but for payments of company tax, would exist a liability for vendors recoupment tax means that, where the liability for that tax is or would be less than $100 and the Commissioner of Taxation exercises his power under the existing law not to pursue the liability, there will be no liability for the relatively small amounts of personal income tax that would otherwise be liable to be recouped.

Where the former owner concerned is a natural person the imputed dividend is to be included in his or her assessable income. In the case of an entity not itself subject to income tax on the dividend by reason of its tax exempt status or, in certain cases, the inter-company dividend rebate, the imputed amount will of course be treated as tax-free income in the hands of that entity.

Where a company, or a person as trustee of a trust, is allocated a dividend that is deemed to have been paid by a stripped company and the owners of that company, or the beneficiaries of that trust, are the same persons as the former owners of the stripped company at the date of its sale, the company or trustee will, in the first instance, be liable to pay dividend recoupment tax on the dividend at the maximum personal rate applicable to the year of income in which the sale or shares occurred.

However, there is to be a right for former owners in this situation to elect to be taxed on amounts equal in total to the amount of the dividend deemed to have been received by the company or trust concerned. If this election is made, and the commissioner is satisfied that the allocation of the deemed dividend among former owners is reasonable and that personal tax, if any, payable by the former owners will, subject to the hardship relief provisions of the income tax law, be paid by them, the interposed company or trust will be freed from its liability for dividend recoupment tax.

In a similar fashion a stripped company will, where a liability for personal tax or dividend recoupment tax exists, be freed from its liability for the income year concerned for undistributed profits tax payable under division 7, and the former owners will accordingly no longer be liable for vendors recoupment tax on an unpaid division 7 liability for that year. A liability for personal tax or dividend recoupment tax will not exist in relation to the profits of a particular year of income where the only unpaid company tax for that year giving rise to a liability for vendors recoupment tax is a liability for undistributed profits tax under division 7 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

As with the existing recoupment tax law it will be possible under the provisions being inserted by this Bill to trace from the primary level to the next level and, as necessary, successively to further levels where a company or trust has ceased to exist, has different shareholders or beneficiaries as a result of shares or beneficial interests having been sold, or is unlikely to be able to meet a liability for dividend recoupment tax on the dividend which is deemed to have been paid to it.

The automatic tracing process applicable in this case will continue until a dividend is deemed to have been paid to a natural person (or tax-free entity referred to earlier) or to a company or trust that still exists if, in the latter situations, the company or trust is one the ownership of which has not changed since the stripped company was sold and has the capacity to meet the dividend recoupment tax payable.

A significant feature of the Bill is the provision of a time-to-pay facility in relation to the personal income tax and dividend recoupment tax liabilities which are to be imposed by this and an associated Bill.

This provision is modelled on an existing facility-which is to be retained in a modified form-which permits former owners of companies who are liable to pay a share of unpaid company tax to meet that liability by instalments, typically over 12 months without late payment penalty being charged.
Additionally, the present Bill also provides for dividend recoupment tax and related personal tax to be paid over 12 months without attracting additional tax for late payment.

The modification of the existing facility I referred to a moment ago is to impose a strict limitation to 12 months as the period for which an arrangement to pay unpaid company tax may be made. Similarly, the proposed facility in relation to personal tax and dividend recoupment tax will require full payment to be made within a period of 12 months if the penalty-free concession is to be attracted.

An application for time to pay personal income tax or dividend recoupment tax in respect of a share of a stripped company's profits will need to be made within 30 days after service of the notice of assessment relating to that liability.
Pre and Post-Sale Avoidance Schemes
The recoupment tax legislation contains a let-out provision that operates where the stripped company was the subject of an unsuccessful post-sale scheme to avoid tax.
Under this escape clause there is no liability to recoupment tax liability on the people who benefited by non-payment of the company tax.
This provision was inserted by the former Government for reasons which are best known to it. In our view it defies logic and it is our announced policy to abolish it.
This is to be done by the Bill.

Consistent with the removal of the post-sale avoidance scheme provision, this Bill will also ensure that, in ascertaining the potential tax liability of a company for the purpose of determining whether the recoupment tax legislation applies in relation to it, any pre-sale scheme which is ultimately established to be ineffective of its tax avoidance purpose is to be disregarded.
Other Changes
There are several further amendments contained in the Bill designed to improve the administration of the legislation or to correct technical deficiencies.

The Bill proposes to remove one of the pre-conditions to liability for recoupment tax-the requirement that the company was by a stripping scheme rendered unable to pay its tax-which was inserted by the previous Government, it seems for presentational purposes.
The element that the requirement expresses is, in substance, present in all cases of pre-tax profit stripping to which the legislation applies and a specific reference to it is quite unnecessary.

It is also proposed by this Bill to re-insert in the recoupment tax legislation a provision removed by the previous Government which authorised the Commissioner of Taxation to report to this Parliament the names of persons who fail to meet their liability for vendors or promoters recoupment tax.

The Commissioner is already required to provide in his annual report to Parliament details of breaches or evasions of the taxation laws and it is consistent with that duty that he be authorised, where he considers it appropriate, to report details of failure to pay recoupment tax.

A further change to the existing recoupment tax law proposed by this Bill will enable a former owner to whom a refund of company tax is made as a result of a successful objection or appeal against the company assessment to receive interest under the Taxation (Interest on Overpayments) Act on the amount refunded.

Finally, this Bill proposes amendments of an evidentiary provision in the existing legislation to overcome some technical deficiencies. The drafting of those amendments also has regard to the views expressed last year by the High Court in a case dealing with the constitutional validity of the recoupment tax legislation.

The High Court held unanimously that the substantive provisions of the recoupment tax legislation are constitutionally valid but in so doing expressed some views that the existing conclusive evidence provision might, at least in part, be invalid by rendering the tax uncontestable.

The proposed amendment provides that a certificate by the Commissioner of Taxation specifying the amount of company tax remaining unpaid would be prima facie, rather than conclusive, evidence of this fact. This will ensure that recoupment tax is not an uncontestable levy and that the evidentiary provision is constitutionally valid in all respects.
As is usual with amendments of the taxation laws, an explanatory memorandum giving technical details of the amendments contained in the Bill is being circulated to honourable senators.

By this Bill the Government proposes to strengthen and improve the legislation introduced by the Opposition parties when in government in 1982. Significantly, the measures contained in this Bill are estimated to yield $270 million in revenue.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
DIVIDEND RECOUPMENT TAX BILL 1985

This Bill is the second of the ''bottom-of-the-harbour'' Bills to which the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce referred in his statement on 22 February 1985. The measures contained in this Bill are identical with those contained in a Bill by a similar title that was introduced on two earlier occasions. On each occasion, the Bill met the same fate in this chamber as did the associated Bill.

This Bill will formally impose a tax-to be called dividend recoupment tax-on the dividend amount determined in accordance with the rules being inserted in the recoupment tax legislation by the amending assessment Bill.
The underlying purpose of the amendments is to recover personal income tax escaped by individual former owners of stripped companies. That will be done in a direct manner wherever possible.

However, in cases where former owners held their shares through interposed companies or trusts, recovery may in certain circumstances be by way of imposing on one or more of the interposed companies or trusts a tax equivalent to the maximum personal rate of tax applying in the year of income in which the shares in the stripped company were sold.
This Bill will impose that tax.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 March, on motion by Senator Jones:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the report of the Senate Select Committee on Video Material. Debate on this took place some three weeks ago, immediately before Easter. As honourable senators will appreciate, at that stage there was very little time available for us to discuss it. That was not the fault of the Government or of the Committee. The report is well researched. Expressions of appreciation have already been enunciated by the Chairman, Senator Jones, to all of those who gave evidence, to the secretariat and of course to the individual members of the Committee. The Committee had a considerable number of items of evidence, heard witnesses and has now presented its report.

SPEECH.PARA: The report indicates that after submissions began arriving in significant numbers it became clear that the overwhelming majority of people making submissions expressed objections to the existence of an X-rated category and the vast majority of these submissions also opposed the proposed DR category. The Committee found that the laws of the Commonwealth relating to video violence and video pornography are inconsistent, that they do not cover a number of possibilities and practices and that the laws either are not fully enforced or are not capable of being fully enforced. On the last occasion this debate took place a number of honourable senators referred to the fact that evidence was received by the Committee that the laws were defective and in some cases were unable to be policed adequately. After considering all the evidence that had been submitted to us, the Committee:

. . . has formed the firm opinion that the current law is unsatisfactory in that it does not adequately control the importation, reproduction, sale or hire of violent, pornographic or obscene material.
The Committee adopted two recommendations which it has submitted to the Senate in this report. I read them as follows:
. . . the Committee recommends that the following interim measures be taken:

(1) A moratorium is placed on the sale and hire of 'X' rated videos in the ACT consistent with the resolution of the Senate of 17 October 1984 as the most practical interim measure to facilitate regulation of videos throughout Australia until the Joint Committee reports.

(2) That the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations be amended, and administrative guidelines issued to Customs Officers be revised, to stop the importation of material that would be refused classification under the Committee's proposal for a moratorium of 'X'-rated and similar material.

Unfortunately to date we do not have the response of the Government to these recommendations of the Committee. By their nature the recommendations are for interim measures, which appear to require urgent action. For example, at present all States either have banned or are to ban X-rated videos. It would be a strange thing indeed if the laws of the Australian Capital Territory were allowed to remain as they are, thus enabling material to be hired or sold from the Australian Capital Territory and sent to other States by post or other means. In addition, the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations now allow to come in material which not only would be prevented from being hired or sold in the States but in fact, as the Committee indicated, would be refused classification by the Film Censorship Board.

That leads me to the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations. We received from the Customs Officers Association evidence of examples of material which on the face of it were prohibited imports, namely, child pornography. The officers concerned seized the material, warrants were issued to search the importer's home and further material was detected. However, the position is, as indicated by the Customs Officers Association and now apparently verified by the Customs Service, that the laws do not enable a charge to be laid against the offender. This raises a question which I raised last year when I said that the amendments to the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations meant that, in the sense that we are discussing it now, there is no such thing as a prohibited import to the extent that charges could be laid and persons could be convicted of an offence. Clearly then the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations must be amended. I quote from page 41, paragraph 4.26, of the report:

An example of the net effect of the current wording of Regulation 4A, and its enforcement, is exemplified in the following recent instance, information about which was supplied by the Customs Officers Association of Australia.
Here is the example:
(a) An individual has in possession an imported film depicting child pornography.

(b) A Customs Officer identifies the film as being one which may 'in the opinion of the Attorney-General or an officer authorised by him' be child pornography, and therefore may be subsequently declared a prohibited import.
(c) The film is referred to the Officer authorised by the Attorney-General, who in turn advises Customs that the film is child pornography, as described in Regulation 4A.
(d) The individual is informed of the decision, but because he has committed no offence, he suffers no punishment, except the loss of the film.

That raises the question whether the law should contain some punitive measures to act as a deterrent. Since we brought down the report there has been only one amendment to the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations. In fact, the amendment was made just prior to our bringing down the report, and it was to do with Regulation 4. I point out, however, that it is drawn to amend Regulation 4 (1A) but in my copy of the regulations there is no such thing. That brings me to the point that those who have been responsible for the drafting of much of this legislation ought to go back to the drawing board quickly so that we have effective laws to prohibit the importation, sale and hire of this material which is offensive to the reasonable adult person.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXTRADITION (COMMONWEALTH COUNTRIES) AMENDMENT BILL 1985EXTRADITION (FOREIGN STATES) AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the sitting of the Senate was suspended for luncheon we were discussing cognately two Bills relating to extradition. The first of these is the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Amendment Bill 1985; the second is the Extradition (Foreign States) Amendment Bill 1985. Both Bills were introduced into the Parliament on 20 March this year, and are very similar in many ways to Bills introduced into the Senate by the previous Attorney-General in May of last year. The purpose of the first Bill is to regulate extradition between Australia and all other Commonwealth countries based on the London scheme agreed to by Commonwealth law Ministers in 1966 and to incorporate amendments to improve the practical operation of the existing legislation. The purpose of the second Bill, the extradition legislation relating to foreign states, is to regulate Australia's extradition relations with countries that are not members of the Commonwealth and with which Australia has extradition arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: As has already been pointed out by a number of speakers both here and in another place, in effect the Bills go some way towards improving our extradition legislation and indeed facilitate extradition procedures resulting from requests made of or by Australia to or from countries which are party to relevant treaties or agreements, whether those countries are foreign states or Commonwealth members. The Bills extend the processes of extradition to include the return of an offender under laws relating to such things as taxation, Customs duties, foreign exchange control and other revenue matters. Presently a person committing these offences is not liable for extradition. The legislation allows, rather quaintly, for voluntary return by a fugitive, if he or she agrees to waive the full extradition process, to the country requesting extradition. I suggest that there is really no big deal in that, although I would say that no harm has been done by including that in the legislation. Voluntarily giving oneself up is going to occur whether or not a procedure for that is provided in the legislation.

One other element of the legislation which raises eyebrows a little is that section which allows that a person extradited may be tried in the country requesting extradition only for the offence or offences which are the basis of the extradition request or application. He or she may not, under this legislation, be tried for any other offences until given a chance to leave the country. I suggest that that is included in the legislation more in the hope that it will be a adhered to by some countries than in any sort of reality. There is, for example, presumably no process of checking whether this is actually done and, human nature being what it is-governments are not exempt from human nature-one would think that even in reasonable democracies there would be a good chance that, having got the person into custody on the grounds for which extradition was granted, not too many opportunities would be given to that person to leave the country again before being tried for some other offences. Certainly, I think Australia would be naive in the extreme to expect that less democratic countries would adhere to that restriction.

The Bills are in many ways relatively innocuous for the most part. I will come back in a moment to the questionable clauses, the ones specifically raised by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. The major part of the interest that the two Bills before us today have raised has come from what is generally known, as the Trimbole affair. Charges and counter-charges have been flung around by both the Government and the Opposition regarding whose fault it is that our extradition laws are in such an unsatisfactory state that the Trimbole affair could have occurred at all. The Opposition has asked the Government to indicate, for example, which of Mr Justice Stewart's 1983 recommendations it has implemented or considered. It is, of course, quite right to do so. It is absurd that we have highly paid people such as Mr Justice Stewart putting a great deal of work, effort and intellect into examining procedures and legislation in this country and making recommendations as a result of that and then seeing them languish in somebody's bottom drawer or somebody else's top shelf for years until someone is prodded into doing something. So I support the Opposition in its questioning of the Government in regard to those recommendations from Mr Justice Stewart.

The Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, on the other hand, as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on 5 April this year, has alleged that the whole Trimbole mess was caused by what he described as bureaucratic inertia which allowed a treaty on which negotiations began in 1972 never to be finalised. Again, presumably, something finished up in somebody else's bottom drawer. Whether it was because of bureaucratic inertia or governmental apathy, this situation was allowed to continue for something like 13 years. One is forced to ask why governments are always so far behind the game, as it were, when it comes to things such as updating mechanisms that will ensure that justice and equity actually occur and are not just talked about. Criminals, it would seem, always manage to keep ahead of these things, and I cannot understand why governments are not able to employ the same brain power, the same lawyers, accountants and so on, to do likewise. If the criminal element can always stay just that little bit in front of law enforcement procedures, I think it is incumbent on governments of all political persuasions to ask themselves why this is so and to make some attempt to avoid it in future and patch it up for the present. There have been some criticisms of the present government for the small amount it has done since the Trimbole affair, but it is just as pertinent to ask why the previous Government allowed our extradition legislation and treaties to become so obsolete that the affair was able to occur at all.

The Scrutiny of Bills Committee, which was established under the previous Government and which I say, as a member of that Committee, does a remarkable amount of work-I see Senator Cooney, who is also a member of that Committee, with no self-interest at all, nodding in agreement-has raised a number of questions about a number of specific clauses in these two Bills. Those are clauses 4, 8 and 9 in the Commonwealth countries legislation and the equivalent clauses in the foreign states legislation. I understand that clause 8, which relates to non-reviewable discretion and concerns the repeal of section 12 of the principal Act, which allowed either a magistrate or the Attorney-General to define what was and was not something of a political nature, has been corrected by the amendments moved by Mr John Spender, QC, in another place, and I will not pursue that matter. Clause 9 relates to the use of search warrants, and I understand from a letter which was received by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee this morning from the Attorney-General that the Government itself is planning to move an amendment to correct what I and the Committee considered was a gross invasion of privacy and a distinct problem with civil liberties.

The remaining clause is clause 4, which is similar to one which was included in the 1984 Bill, to which the Scrutiny of Bills Committee drew the Senate's attention at that time. Essentially, it delegates extensive powers away from the Parliament in a manner which the Committee considered could be quite inappropriate. The clause is a complex and long one, but it boils down to the fact that a new section 4A is intended to be inserted into the principal Act which would, if it went through, allow changes to be made to the Schedule by regulation rather than by legislation. Those changes would include altering an item, adding or omitting an item or substituting a new item for an existing item. Mr Bowen's letter to the Committee said that he did not share the Committee's concern. His argument was:

. . . where a convention imposes an obligation to create offences for which signatories agree to extradite then an Act of Parliament will be required to create those offences for the purposes of domestic law.
He went on to say:

Having created the offences it should be unnecessary for the Parliament to reconsider the question in relation to the extradition legislation and it is appropriate for the Regulations to modify the Schedule in the extradition legislation so as to encompass those offences.

I would have thought that it was not too much to expect of the Parliament that, if we are dealing already with one Act of Parliament which is required to create the offences for the purposes of domestic law, we could deal by way of legislation with consequential amendments required to change the schedule. I put that apparently rather naive theory to both the Opposition and the Government today. I was delighted to receive approval from both sides of the Senate, which indicates that on occasions sanity does prevail in this chamber. You will be pleased to know, Mr Deputy President, that I will now not have to go on at some length during the Committee stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might have been just peace and quiet that he was seeking.

—That could be so. It may be that I just made such a jolly nuisance of myself that everybody caved in, but I am sure that sweet reason prevailed instead. The Democrats will be moving at the Committee stage that clause 4 be deleted and we will be quite delighted to receive the support of both the Liberal Opposition and the Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important that the processes of extradition should not be used by criminals or fugitive offenders to avoid apprehension and trial for their actions. Control of international crime is needed. Nevertheless, this has to be balanced against political oppression of dissenters. We must allow those who flee from a country safe exile. I think these Bills go some way towards achieving that although I would share the opinion of Opposition members in another place and, indeed, here that balance needs to go a little beyond that which has been achieved in the two Bills before us today and that more work has to be done to update our extradition arrangements. Having said that, the Bills go some way towards that and the Australian Democrats will, with the exception of clause 4, be supporting the legislation.

'(2) Sub-section (1) does not authorize a Police Officer to remove, or to require the person to remove, any of the clothing that the person is wearing.

'(3) A Police Officer may seize any article found as a result of a search in accordance with sub-section (1) and may retain any article so seized pending any direction from the Attorney-General as to the manner in which the article is to be dealt with.
'(4) The powers conferred by this section are in addition to, and not in derogation of, any other powers conferred by law.
'(5) In this section, ''Police Officer'' means a member or special member of the Australian Federal Police or a member of the Police Force of a State or Territory.
Search warrants

'16B. (1) Where an information on oath is laid before a Magistrate alleging that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that there may be upon any land or upon or in any premises, vessel, aircraft or vehicle, any article, including a sum of money, that may be material as evidence in proving an offence to which the requisition for the surrender of a person relates or that has been acquired by a person as a result of such an offence, and the information sets out those grounds, the Magistrate may issue a search warrant in accordance with the appropriate form prescribed for the purposes of this sub-section authorizing a Police Officer named in the warrant, with such assistance as the Police Officer thinks necessary, and if necessary by force-
(a) to enter upon the land or upon or into the premises, vessel, aircraft or vehicle;
(b) to search the land, premises, vessel, aircraft or vehicle for any such article; and
(c) to seize any such article found upon the land or upon or in the premises, vessel, aircraft or vehicle.
'(2) A Magistrate shall not issue a warrant under sub-section (1) unless-

(a) the informant or some other person has given to the Magistrate, either orally or by affidavit, such further information (if any) as the Magistrate requires concerning the grounds on which the issue of the warrant is being sought; and
(b) the Magistrate is satisfied that there are reasonable grounds for issuing the warrant.
'(3) There shall be stated in a warrant issued under this section-
(a) a statement of the purpose for which the warrant is issued, which shall include a reference to the nature of the offence in relation to which the entry and search are authorized;
(b) whether entry is authorized to be made at any time of the day or night or during specified hours of the day or night;
(c) a description of the kind of articles authorized to be seized; and
(d) a day, not being later than one month after the day of issue of the warrant, upon which the warrant ceases to have effect.

'(4) If, in the course of searching in accordance with a warrant issued under this section, for an article, including a sum of money, that may be material as evidence in proving an offence or has been acquired as result of an offence, being an article of a kind specified in the warrant, a Police Officer finds any article, including a sum of money, that the Police Officer believes on reasonable grounds to be connected with the offence, although not of a kind specified in the warrant, and the Police Officer believes on reasonable grounds that it is necessary to seize that article in order to prevent its concealment, loss or destruction, the warrant shall be deemed to authorize the Police Officer to seize that article.

'(5) Where a Police Officer seizes an article found as a result of a search in accordance with this section, the Police Officer may retain the article pending any direction from the Attorney-General as to the manner in which the article is to be dealt with.
'(6) In this section, ''Police Officer'' has the same meaning as in section 16A.'.''.

The amendments cover similar territory, to the provisions contained in the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Amendment Bill relating to search warrants. What is new, so far as the Extradition (Foreign States) Amendment Bill is concerned, is a further provision which relates only to this Bill. It does not relate to the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Amendment Bill. This relates to the creation of a proposed new sub-section 9 (1B) which creates a Schedule listing the countries to which the Act applies by virtue of the existence of a so-called inherited treaty. The amendment that I have moved in this respect simply provides that where one of these inherited treaties is replaced by a modern treaty the reference in the Schedule to the relevant country shall be in effect omitted. The amendment thereby removes the need to amend the Schedule in the Act whenever a modern treaty replaces an inherited treaty. It is a purely technical matter, but that is the explanation for it. It has been the subject of a detailed explanatory memorandum, as have the search warrant provisions. I understand that it is non-controversial.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADMINISTRATION OF FAMILY LAW IN AUSTRALIA

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 April, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Notice Paper states that I am in continuation. The Senate is considering the report of the Family Law Council entitled 'Administration of Family Law in Australia'. In June 1984 the then Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, wrote to the Family Law Council seeking its advice upon the issues of the image of the Family Court of Australia and the public's perception of the operations of the court, and raising particular aspects of those matters. The Council prepared a consultation paper which was distributed widely. The Council received a number of submissions on that paper. The paper is concerned with the more practical day to day aspects of family law in Australia. I quote from Mr Justice Fogarty, the Chairman of the Family Law Council, in his introductory statement:

SPEECH.PARA: It makes a number of recommendations to the Attorney-General the implementation of which the Council believes is essential if Family Law in Australia is to function at a satisfactory level.

On the last occasion I spoke to this report I had not had a great deal of time to study it. I have now had some time to study it. The more I look at the report the more I believe it really deals with superficialities and, in fact, may not achieve the intended result. The intended result is implicit in the letter that was written by the then Attorney-General to the Family Law Council when he sought advice from the Council upon the issues of the image of the Family Court and the public's perception of the operation of the court. I do know whether the rather superficial recommendations that have been made in this document will do that. When I say superficial I do not use that term in a derogatory fashion. Mr Justice Fogarty, the Chairman of the Council, does say that the paper is concerned with the more practical day to day aspects of family law in Australia. That is the manner in which I use the term. There is no disrespect to the Family Law Council and Mr Justice Fogarty. I used the term in the sense that Mr Justice Fogarty is saying in effect that the paper is concerned with the more practical day to day aspects of family law in Australia, such as whether wigs should be worn, the location of the courts, the size and formality of the courtrooms, public waiting space, conference facilities, court staff, robing, control over the passage of cases, et cetera. These matters are important in the day to day running of the Family Court and of any court, but in the administration of justice in Australia they are, to anyone's examination, peripheral. Just because you, Mr Acting Deputy President, are not wearing a wig it does not mean that I have less respect for you. I suppose these are the questions about which lawyers want to argue. I believe there is need for a far deeper analysis of the problems of the administration of family law in this country and, therefore, the public's perception of the operations of the court which administers the Family Law Act.

Some recommendations are important, although they are superficial. Some are a little less superficial than others. For example, the Council has made certain recommendations about the importance of marriage counselling. Paragraph 3.16 at page 57 of the report states:
In principle, therefore, the Council considers that the very important function of marriage counselling should be carried out by approved marriage counselling organisations.
The report goes on to say:
. . . in some instances persons who initially seek the assistance of the Court Counselling Section for conciliation counselling may actually be seeking reconciliation counselling.

Marriage counselling has now been redefined to include pre-marriage counselling. We did that I think last year. I believe this is an area to which more and more attention should be given. It is very important that persons intending marriage understand what it is all about. Obviously it is almost an impossibility to understand what it is all about. A person could be married 25 years and not know what it is all about. Such a person should at least have an understanding of the principles which should apply when entering the institution of marriage. Marriage, as defined by law under the provisions of the marriage legislation, is the union of a man and woman voluntarily entered into exclusively for life. Persons who approach that important step in life ought to have some understanding of what it is all about.

There have been suggestions around this chamber for some time that maybe it is time to follow the example that has been given by some churches which insist that the intending couples go through a period of instruction and marriage counselling. I see Senator Watson nodding and I understand that he has made similar suggestions that that would be well worth considering. I understand that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and, indeed, the previous Attorney-General-to be fair to him-were most concerned and most interested to see that more money was made available to marriage counselling organisations for the purposes of pre-marriage counselling. Unfortunately, whilst the will has been there, the budgetary result has not. I hope that in the forthcoming Budget a decent amount will be set aside for that purpose.

Obviously the Council is suggesting also that reconciliation counselling is best done by approved marriage counselling organisations. I would generally agree with that. Because those organisations are community-based they have a fair amount of voluntary input. Generally the people who are engaged in reconciliation counselling are properly equipped to do so. Nevertheless, it is important also that the counsellors be sufficiently trained. They may have all the good will in the world. They may understand, through experience, what marriage is all about. They may understand all about the relationships involved in the marriage-not only between the partners but also between the partners and their children-but it is a different matter to be able to get that across.

Also, there may be a threat to the marriage when there is extreme pressure on the marriage-it could be financial pressure or it could be pressure for a number of reasons, including psychological reasons. Reconciliation counsellors must be trained in order to detect the causes, to solve the problem and to bring about the reconciliation. Of course, this sort of training also needs money. I know that a number of honourable senators have received copies of letters that have been sent to the Government about the need for more resources for counsellors to undertake the very important task they are undertaking in Australia.

It is clear from this document that the Family Court has virtually abandoned reconciliation counselling. Its counselling services are concentrated on conciliation-namely, counselling for divorce, counselling on the division of property, counselling on access to children and the like. I believe that if that is entrenched too far it may be a backward step because very often the first point of contact, when there is a conflict within a marriage, is the Family Court.

The report says somewhere-I cannot quote it-that it is important that counsellors in the Court Counselling Section are aware of agencies to which persons may be more appropriately referred, including the authorised marriage counselling organisations. Nevertheless, I believe that the counselling service and the Court have an obligation to raise with the party that comes to it in the first instance the question of the effect of the proposed dissolution. In other words, the Court should advise the party that he or she should give consideration to the legal, social and financial consequences of a dissolution of the marriage and, in particular, to the effects of a dissolution of the marriage on any children of the marriage. I think it is very important that the Court has that responsibility, even before any proceedings have been taken.

As we all know, section 14 of the Act provides that where proceedings have been instituted the judge or magistrate and the parties' legal representatives must give consideration to the possibility of reconciliation between the parties. Under the provisions of the Act the judge or the magistrate and the legal representatives are required to do that. Consistent with, I think, section 46 of the Family Law Act, the Counselling Section of the Court must give that priority. It must in a realistic and understanding manner raise that question with the party which may be the first to come to it or which may eventually come to it.

The concentration wholly on divorce counselling gives me a good deal of concern. It gives me a little more concern when I see that the Council is recommending the separation of the conciliation and judicial functions of the Court. On the face of it, that might seem a reasonable thing to do-get conciliation away from the judge and have the counsellors deal with the matter in that way. I would agree with that if we were talking about reconciliation counselling. But when the stage is reached that the parties are determined to proceed towards a divorce-an application has been made and all the procedures have been gone through-it is envisaged by this recommendation that they will go through the conciliation processes distinct from references to the judge. Whilst that might seem appropriate, I believe that it might have an outcome which is undesirable and which may not have been foreseen. Might it not, in effect, prevent the right of a party to be heard?

I put it to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that one of the most important things in the administration of the law is that justice not only be done but be seen to be done. An effective denial of the right of a party to be heard is really a denial of that principle. Admittedly, the law in this area, in my opinion, is defective and the administration of the law is made so much more difficult. But the public's perception of the Family Court would fall even lower than it is at present if the separation of the conciliation and judicial functions were to result in the establishment of a bureaucracy which was concerned simply with counselling for divorce, a process which the parties were forced to attend, leaving them with the feeling that their case would be bogged down if they did not go through that process in a manner which resolved the dispute. When I say 'resolve the dispute', I am referring to the determination of who should have access to the children and how the property should be divided. These are very important issues. I feel that when the principle of fault was done away with the sense of injustice was heightened amongst persons who in many cases not only felt they they were wronged but in fact were wronged. The low public perception of the administration of family law in Australia arises from that situation.

From time to time we have all received letters from constituents. Sometimes after speaking in the Senate we receive letters from people who are not constituents. That is why I am diffident about speaking about this issue now. I might as well say: 'Please don't write to me if you live in another State because I am a senator for the State of Tasmania'. But we receive letters from all over Australia. I refer to a recent situation relating to a person living on a farm in a particular State which returned a marginal income. His wife deserted him and he found just over a year later that he had to fight an application for dissolution of marriage in another State. The applicant was provided with legal aid but this individual, because of the tests that are applied, was not granted legal aid. I am sure that those in authority know of such cases. They must be concerned about it. However, the brief of the Family Law Council on this occasion apparently was not sufficient to cover that sort of case; nor was the brief sufficient to cover the type of amendments to the Family Law Act which are required to enhance within the public's mind the view of the Family Court as administering an appropriate and just law. As I said before, the view that is taken-and quite properly taken in many areas-is that the law is not just and therefore the administration of the law is defective.

We have reached the stage in our society when I believe we must address ourselves again to the adequacy of the family law legislation. Recently, Katherine West wrote an article about the immense poverty that is being experienced by people in this country as a result of marriage breakdown. Pressures are being applied on public housing and the public purse as a result of marriage breakdown. The cost to the Commonwealth alone of marriage breakdown this year was in the vicinity of $1.2 billion. That factor is most disconcerting. Of course, the greatest problem is the individual trauma and pain that is involved in separation and divorce, and particularly the trauma that is experienced by children. The number of children who have been affected by divorce since 1976 has reached almost half a million. The cumulative figures that I have, which apply until the end of 1983-a year and three months ago-show that 465,765 children have been affected as a result of divorce in Australia. These statistics do not tell the full story. It is a tragic story.

I come back to the point that whilst some of the suggestions are suitable and will assist in the day to day running of the court, I believe that it is time that the Attorney-General had another good look at the family law legislation in order to suggest amendments which would enhance and strengthen the institution of marriage and which would give the utmost consideration to those couples who are now in strife and who are looking for help. Very often when they see a lawyer, despite what is contained in the legislation, the lawyer will say: 'Section 14 states that you must consider reconciliation, but the marriage is finished and there is no point in that. We will go ahead'. The legislation should provide practical encouragement for persons who are considering divorce to attend a conference with an expert marriage counsellor who will talk to both parties so that they can consider the social, legal and financial consequences of a dissolution of marriage, and particularly the consequences for the children. I have here-and I am sorry that I have not shown this document to the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), who is at the table-the amendments to the legislation that I proposed two years ago. I seek permission to have the document incorporated in Hansard. I also apologise to Senator Lewis for not showing it to him.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 April, on motion by Senator Walters:

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday time limitations denied me the opportunity of finalising my remarks in support of the recommendation by the Human Rights Commission that heroin be made available to the terminally ill patients who cannot obtain effective relief through other treatment or drugs. I believe quite strongly that the terminally ill have the right to decide for themselves in their last hours how they wish their illness to be treated. In the final stages of illness, the physical condition, especially of cancer patients, may make the oral administration of drugs difficult or impossible. For an emaciated patient who has little muscle tissue left continual large doses of morphia by injections lead to more pain and more discomfort. Therefore, the procedure of using a small volume injection is clearly the most humane practice. However diamorphine hydrochloride or heroin is not seen as a panacea for terminal cancer but it should be available to those to whom it can be of some benefit in controlling pain.

SPEECH.PARA: A question not covered in the report, and which I believe must be examined in the future, is that of the right of total patient care for the terminally ill. It is the sort of care that is available only for hospice-type situations to enable the terminally ill to die with a degree of dignity. Therefore, I totally support the recommendations of the Human Rights Commission in relation to the right of terminally ill patients to have access to heroin for pain-taking purposes.
